Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: A Spatial Theory of Trophic Cascades in Omnivory Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Identifying the characteristics of communities that affect their responses to perturbations is a primary goal of both fundamental and applied ecology. Trophic cascades occur when predators reduce their prey, indirectly affecting lower trophic levels such as plants. This project combines mathematical models and their predictions with experiments to determine why trophic cascades vary across diverse communities. The investigators propose that omnivores - organisms that eat both animals and plants - will stabilize communities based on convincing preliminary data. This hypothesis will be tested using experimental food webs consisting of mixed bacteria as resources, a single-celled prey species, a protist predator, and a protist omnivore. The investigators will manipulate colonization rates across experimental communities and measure changes in the mathematical stability of each community in response to these manipulations. Models will be fit to time series of data to provide new insights into the causes underlying change in the structure and stability of omnivorous food webs.

Support for this project will significantly improve an ongoing doctoral dissertation project that has combined mathematical models with field experiments to suggest that colonization rates result in consistent changes in trophic cascades. The training of a promising young scientist will be enhanced as a result. The project will involve a diverse assemblage of undergraduates who will perform research at the interface of biology and mathematics. Through participation in the United States Department of Education RISE program, the investigators integrate deserving students underrepresented in science fields into research labs when they transfer from local community colleges. These students will receive training in microscopy, experimental design, mathematical modeling, statistical analyses and basic usage of several computer programming environments. Results from the research will improve efforts to curb human alteration of habitats, production of commercially-valuable crops, and control of animal vectors that spread human disease.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human land use is eroding historical patterns of habitat connectivity. At the same time, human activities like the movement of nutrients are affecting Earth’s basal resources, causing changes in bottom-up regulation of ecosystems that cascade up food webs to prey and predators. We combined mathematical models and experiments with small laboratory bacteria-protist ecosystems in order to assess the interplay between changes in habitat connectivity and bottom-up regulation in simplified ecological systems comprising interacting species with fast generation times. Namely, we manipulated habitat connectivity and bacterial growth rates in small replicate laboratory ecosystems and studied the effects of these manipulations on community- and population-level dynamics of the constituent species. We observed non-intuitive system dynamics and emergent trophic structures that were poorly explained by a suite of mathematical models. This is strongly suggestive of an effect of some unaccounted ecological driver not included in typical food web models. We have pinpointed an idiosyncratic life history strategy of one of the protist species studied here, Blepharisma americanum — under certain abiotic and biotic conditions, individuals of this species transform into giant-celled cannibalistic polymorphs that later divide into approximately 10-15 new normal-sized individuals. We suspect that this life history strategy and associated lagged birth pulse are strong candidates for explaining the apparent mismatch between theory developed here and experimental data. Additional studies designed to characterize when and why Blepharisma undergoes this transformation are currently underway. The hope is that data obtained from these experiments can be used to develop and parameterize new mathematical models that will explain results from the present experiment. These ancillary experiments have also provided further opportunities to train undergraduate mentees in ecology, mathematics, experimental design, statistics and microscopy. 

PI Anderson and co-PI Fahimipour have been very successful in mentoring undergraduates over the course of the present research project; we have worked directly with 8 undergraduates, consisting of 4 women, 2 Asian Americans, 3 Hispanics, and one US Army veteran. Of these students, 5 have participated in work-study for course credit at the University of California, Riverside. At the end of each academic term, PI Anderson and co-PI Fahimipour assessed the performance and contribution of each of our undergraduates and indicated areas for further improvement. Once our undergraduates have become proficient in our lab, those exhibiting an interest in ecology were encouraged to develop independent projects. To date, these independent projects have resulted in students’ dissemination of findings through a variety of avenues including both oral and poster presentations at UCR’s undergraduate research symposia.
